author: Trevor Hoey
title: Odds favour Echo Entertainment Group
text:
Shares in the operator of the Star, Treasury and Jupiters casinos have gained about 40 per cent in less than six months. by Trevor Hoey In the face of extreme market volatility, shares in Echo Entertainment Group hit a new high on Monday and there appears to be little standing in the way of further increases.
Shares in the operator of the Star, Treasury and Jupiters casinos have gained about 40 per cent in less than six months after a strong interim result and management's comments that it was expecting the second half of fiscal 2015 to be consistent with the six months to December 31, 2014.
To the contrary it has been a horror period for Crown Resorts, with its shares falling 25 per cent between February and June because of poor performances from its casino interests in Macau.
However, Crown rebounded last week, most likely driven by the imminent decision regarding the Queen's Wharf Brisbane casino and hotel project. A decision regarding the awarding of the project is expected to be handed down in July and while the Crown/Greenland consortium could be successful, Echo shouldn't be written off.
Deutsche Bank said the group remained well positioned with its tender, given it would seek to include its existing facilities in the project rather than seeking additional gaming machines. The fact that it will have a stronger focus on tourism than the competing tender is expected to work in its favour.
To exclude this level of uncertainty from its valuation, in the process of revisiting its full-year projections for Echo, Deutsche Bank reduced its revised valuation by 1.5 per cent to reflect the probability of the group not being awarded the Queen's Wharf project.
Taking these adjustments into account, the broker upgraded its net profit forecast for fiscal 2015 by 5 per cent to $214.1 million and increased the 12-month price target from $5.10 to $5.35. This partly reflects industry strength in domestic gaming, as well as market share gains.
